Equity Bank CEO, Dr. James Mwangi A while back, Equity Bank issued a security alert to its customers owing to a malware in circulation that targeted customers using its eBanking platform. The malware Â was distributed via fake emails purportedly to coming from the bank. The malware contained a link namedÂ  â€œClick Here To Activate Your Accountâ€, which when clicked automatically downloaded and installed into the victimâ€™s computer and attempted to steal their login information. Keen on boosting the security of its digital channels, Equity Bank has signed a deal Â South African cyber security firm Entersekt, to deploy its security multi-authentication solutions Transakt and InteraktÂ on Equity Bankâ€™sÂ online banking, mobile banking, and payment platforms. Equity will integrateÂ Transakt software development kit into its mobile applications thus enablingÂ multi-factor authentication of online banking, mobile banking, mobile money transfer and e-commerce. This will create anÂ isolated communication channel between the device and financial institution that avoids reliance on the open Internet for user and transaction verification.Â Most of Equity bankâ€™s customers still use USSD products necessitating the deployment ofÂ push-USSDâ€“based authentication product, Interakt. Last year, Cybersecurity firm Serianu published theÂ Kenya Cyber Security Report 2015 that showedÂ vast majority of private companies and public sector organizations Â remain very exposed to cyber crime and internal IT fraud with 70% of them exposed to cyber-criminal attacks. TheÂ report stated that the annual cost of cybercrime to Kenyan companies is estimated to be Kshs. 15 billion (USD146 Million). On an industry basis,Â the public sector is the most affected having losing approximately Kshs 5 billion per year followed by the financial services sector at Kshs 4 billion and manufacturing and industrial at Kshs 3 billion in third place. The telecommunications, media and technology and other sectors are estimated to loseÂ  about Kshs 2 billion and Kshs 1 billion respectively.  Eric writes on business, govt policy and enterprise tech.
